FIELDINGS FRIDAY FACT Action Man was launched 1966 by Palitoy. He was known by his scar on his face. Why did he have a scar?   The manufacturers could not legally copyright a human face, but by adding the scar this became his trademark and therefore copyright could be granted. https://t.co/xyAjUCshZy

@MB_GB_4 @herdyshepherd1 @RoryStewartUK I have no doubt that methane emissions play their part but the growing of soya, usually in Brazil, and  wheat, often on the plains of the US, and their transportation has a bigger impact on CO2 levels and biodiversity.

@farrantshayes @rachellaudan @Marilyn_Res @herdyshepherd1 Very true, and that slight drop in body weight through the winter also puts the cow in a better condition for the upcoming calving, ie not too fat

@rachellaudan @Marilyn_Res @herdyshepherd1 And also puzzling that you would think that these production methods would result in low quality food? These are basically historic, natural methods of food production which produces higher quality food, better for human health (no antibiotics) and better for the environment?

@rachellaudan @herdyshepherd1 @Marilyn_Res That’s really interesting that a food historian would think that keeping animals inside for winter is the norm? Animals have only been in-wintered in any number in relatively recent years? Beef production, historically, was all outside reared.

@bignagtheory @herdyshepherd1 You save areas ungrazed through the summer which can then be used to graze throughout the winter, or on some hills we stock at a level where the herbage out grows what the cows can eat in the summer, and then they have sufficient left to get them through the winter
@herdyshepherd1 Ditto

@MB_GB_4 @herdyshepherd1 @RoryStewartUK No it’s not, it’s growing the grain (and soya) and the transportation of that grain (and soya) that goes to feed the vast majority of the cows in the World that is the problem.

Gregory Warren Wilson’s colourful and innovative sculptural work in glass plays with the translucent nature of the material and the interactions of colours. Each piece is conceived using multiple layers of hand-cut Murano allowing light to interact with the glass spatially. https://t.co/kB61cbvg8m

Ireland’s master basket maker, Joe Hogan creates non-functional durable baskets that incorporate wood, bark, larch, birch, bog-myrtle, catkins and home-grown willow.
